page.title: 18Birds in the Girvan Valley
page.content: There are both common and rare birds in the Girvan Valley. The more widely seen birds include { {blackbirds, yellowhammers, finches, {house martins and carrion crows.}The increase in number of these crows has affected other birds such as{larks and {lapwings}causing their numbers to diminish. Modern farming has affected many birds, most recently the{corncrake,} which has disappeared from the Girvan Valley in the last 10 years. On the R. Girvan it is possible to see a breeding pair of swans and on the higher ground there are{kestrels, {sparrowhawks and a pair of buzzards. Being near the coast means that many {gulls}can also be seen with{herring {and blackbacked gulls}the most common. In winter{redwing and fieldfare} migrate south and are seen till spring
